Standard play so far.
I could have recaptured with the Knight, but I thought having powerful, united central Pawns was more important than centralizing my horseman.

Black could have been aggressive with the pinning move 6... B-QN5, but instead chooses to retreat. I could have responded with 7 P-QR3 forcing the exchange of minor pieces if Black doesn't want his Bishop trapped.
I offer an exchange of B's and clear the way for castling.
Black chooses to retreat to a square where I can still exchange B's. Apparently he wants me to initiate it...
...which I do...
...and he completes it.
Now, on to castling.
Black clears the way for castling. However, he never completes the job by actually moving his King into safety...
I aim to seize Q-side space. There's also the possiblity of trapping the B...
...which Black negates by creating a cubbyhole.
Having failed to castle when he had the chance, Black now has to forfeit the privilege.
Now my Rook controls the open file.
With Black unable to play ...P-KR3, I take advantage with an aggressive pin.
This move is pointless, as the Bishop is guarded. Black certainly isn't going to trade his Rook for it...
I merely aim to force Black's B backwards.
This move contains a hidden danger.
Black's best line is 14... QxQ 15 QRxQ B-R2. His position would be very cramped but he'd at least maintain immediate survival. Instead...
..he commits a disastrous blunder. Black has forgotten that his QN is blocking the Rook from guarding his first rank...
...and this move wraps it up.
